Hi Andy,

I suspect this sort of thing has been proposed before, which does=
n't mean
it shouldn't be proposed again or in a different context, but does=
 mean
that perhaps there's some prior research around it.

One thing which =
does come to mind is that by starting with a fixed partial
solution you are=
 effectively starting the entire population on some
non-optimal peak in the=
 fitness landscape, which is the point of your
suggestion I think: why star=
t at the bottom when there are typically simple
ways of getting "part way" =
there. However "part way" means starting on some
non-optimal peak in a comp=
lex fitness landscape; ie EAs don't follow a
linear progression from some l=
ow point to some high point in the fitness
landscape (except for the most t=
rivial problems): when attempting to avoid
"reinventing the wheel" with the=
 LRC you might end up inventing the wrong
wheel with it. Thus the populatio=
n may become stranded around this peak
(depending on mutation rates, etc) a=
nd so not able to find better/optimal
solutions. Of course this is a major =
potential problem with any EA, but I
do wonder if starting the entire genom=
e on some non-optimal peak would
exacerbate the problem.

Points 4 and 5 wo=
uld go some way (perhaps a very significant way) towards
mitigating this, b=
ut I think really you just end up trading off how far up
the non-optimal pe=
ak you start with how likely you are to getting stuck on
that peak (which i=
s perhaps your point, and not a bad thing). So, it would
be good to see som=
e research to see how useful this sort of thing really is
(anyone?).

Cheer=
s,
Oliver

 On 22 November 2011 09:34, afcarl2 <afcarl2@...> wrote:

> A suggestion for a generic 1st order "concept", to be held invio=
late
> withing the genome (direct or indirect encoding):
> Linear Regressio=
n/Classification (LRC) hypothesis model, based upon the
> following:
> 1) M=
odel selection of included polynomial terms based upon minimization of
> de=
lta error between training and cross-validation errors,
> 2) LRC embedded w=
ithin single multi-input/output node of start genome,
> 3) Start genome con=
figured w/ LRC embedded node with input weights of 1.0
> to each correspond=
ing input of genome,
> 4) Start genome configured w/ LRC embedded node with=
 scaled output w/
> weights of 1.0 to each corresponding output of genome,
=
> 5) Start genome configured w/ LRC embedded node with scaled outputs for
>=
 each polynomial term within the LRC model, yet not connected,
> 6) LRC int=
erior functionality held inviolate within genome,
> The resulting start gen=
ome should have the following characteristics:
> a) Start performance equiv=
alent to LRC,
> b) LRC interior complexity does not contribute to dimension=
al operator
> disruption,
> c) All significant LRC interior non-linear term=
s are available for
> additional complexification if justifiable,
> The rat=
ional for this suggestion as follows:
> i. Computational overhead for devel=
opment of the LRC is expended once,
> ii. Computational overhead for LRC hy=
pothesis model selection is low,
> iii. Computational process for developme=
nt of the LRC is well understood,
> iv. There is no good reason to re-inven=
t the wheel, corresponding to the
> cost of evolving rudimentary performanc=
e equivalent of the LRC in NN
> formative elements,
> v. LRC interior non-l=
inear terms are available for complexification, and
> therefore do not requ=
ire evolutionary development from NN formative
> elements,
> vi. The genera=
l truism, that it is usually easier/faster/quicker to modify
> and improve =
something that is in-the-ballpark, than start from scratch.
>
> Andy

Hi Andy,<div><br></div><div>I suspect this sort of thing has been proposed =
before, which doesn't mean it shouldn't be proposed again or in a d=
ifferent context, but does mean that perhaps there's some prior researc=
h around it.</div>
<div><br></div><div>One thing which does come to mind is=
 that by starting with a fixed partial solution you are effectively startin=
g the entire population on some non-optimal peak in the fitness landscape, =
which is the point of your suggestion I think: why start at the bottom when=
 there are typically simple ways of getting "part way" there. How=
ever "part way" means starting on some non-optimal peak in a comp=
lex fitness landscape; ie EAs don't follow a linear progression from so=
me low point to some high point in the fitness landscape (except for the mo=
st trivial problems): when attempting to avoid "reinventing the wheel&=
quot; with the LRC you might end up inventing the wrong wheel with it. Thus=
 the population may become stranded around this peak (depending on mutation=
 rates, etc) and so not able to find better/optimal solutions. Of course th=
is is a major potential problem with any EA, but I do wonder if starting th=
e entire genome on some non-optimal peak would exacerbate the problem.</div=
>
<div><br></div><div>Points 4 and 5 <span style=3D"background-color:rgb(25=
5,255,255);color:rgb(34,34,34);font-family:arial,sans-serif;font-size:13px"=
>would go some way (perhaps a very significant way) towards mitigating this=
, but I think really you just end up trading off how far up the non-optimal=
 peak you start with how likely you are to getting stuck on that peak (whic=
h is perhaps your point, and not a bad thing). So, it would be good to see =
some research to see how useful this sort of thing really is (anyone?).</sp=
an></div>
<div><br></div><div>Cheers,</div><div>Oliver</div><div><br><div c=

  =
    
      
      <p>A suggestion for a generic 1st order "concept&quo=
t;, to be held inviolate withing the genome (direct or indirect encoding):<=
br>
Linear Regression/Classification (LRC) hypothesis model, based upon the=
 following:<br>
1) Model selection of included polynomial terms based upon =
minimization of delta error between training and cross-validation errors,<b=
r>
2) LRC embedded within single multi-input/output node of start genome,<b=
r>
3) Start genome configured w/ LRC embedded node with input weights of 1.=
0 to each corresponding input of genome,<br>
4) Start genome configured w/ =
LRC embedded node with scaled output w/ weights of 1.0 to each correspondin=
g output of genome,<br>
5) Start genome configured w/ LRC embedded node wit=
h scaled outputs for each polynomial term within the LRC model, yet not con=
nected,<br>
6) LRC interior functionality held inviolate within genome,<br>=

The resulting start genome should have the following characteristics:<br>
=
a) Start performance equivalent to LRC,<br>
b) LRC interior complexity does=
 not contribute to dimensional operator disruption,<br>
c) All significant =
LRC interior non-linear terms are available for additional complexification=
 if justifiable,<br>
The rational for this suggestion as follows:<br>
i. Co=
mputational overhead for development of the LRC is expended once,<br>
ii. C=
omputational overhead for LRC hypothesis model selection is low,<br>
iii. C=
omputational process for development of the LRC is well understood,<br>
iv.=
 There is no good reason to re-invent the wheel, corresponding to the cost =
of evolving rudimentary performance equivalent of the LRC in NN formative e=
lements,<br>
v. LRC interior non-linear terms are available for complexific=
ation, and therefore do not require evolutionary development from NN format=
ive elements,<br>
vi. The general truism, that it is usually easier/faster/=
quicker to modify and improve something that is in-the-ballpark, than start=
 from scratch.<br>
<br>
Andy<br>
<br>
</p>
